without anything further, please join me in

132.text:
Senator Barack Obama. Thanks.
>> OBAMA: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you,

167.text:
every body. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you

good to be back in Mountain View and it's

232.text:
strict dress code.

something improbable about this gathering.

ago that Larry and Sergey got together in

256.text:
idea to organize all of the world's information

262.text:
I was an Illinois state senator doing my best

267.text:
dreams. What we shared is a belief in changing

275.text:

283.text:
also shared a bunch of student loans that
still needed to be paid off. And you would

289.text:
have found it hard to predict that Larry and
Sergey would now be the co-founders of one

294.text:
of the most successful companies in recent
history and that I would be standing on this

300.text:

307.text:

314.text:
about what I believe we have to do together,
to seize this moment with a sense of purpose

321.text:

327.text:

we also know that the Google story is more

334.text:
than just being about the bottom line. It's
about seeing what we can accomplish when we

340.text:
believe in things that are unseen, when we
take the measure of our changing times and

346.text:
we take action to shape them. And that's why
we're here today, that's why many of you decided

352.text:
to work here instead of someplace else. Technology
and innovation have reshaped our economy and

358.text:
our lives at breathtaking speed. America's
been fighting to figure out how to tap this

367.text:
awesome new resource that we have, and Google
has helped to show us the way. But the story

372.text:
is far from over. Google’s story is far
from over. The story of how we shaped our

377.text:
changing times is far from over. What comes
next depends on the choices that we make right

384.text:
now, at this moment, in this election. We
could see the spirit of innovation that started

392.text:
this company be stifled. We could see the
internet divided up to the highest bidders.

399.text:
We could see a government that uses technology
to shut people out, instead of letting them

404.text:
in. Tax break shuffled to special interests
while the next start-up, the next Google can't

410.text:
get a fair shot. Challenges like healthcare
and energy that hold our country back while

417.text:
competition from other nations picks up. That's
one alternative. Another alternative is for

425.text:
us to unlock a new future of opportunity.
Together we could open up the government and

430.text:
invite all citizens in while connecting all
of America to 21st century Broadband. We could

437.text:
use technology to help achieve universal healthcare,
to reach for a clean energy future, and to

444.text:
ensure that young Americans can compete and
win in the global economy. If America recommits

451.text:
itself to science and innovation, then we
can lead the world to a new future of productivity

459.text:
and prosperity. That's what we can do if we
seize this moment. That's the choice we face.

to write the next chapter in the story of

472.text:
American innovation. That's part of the reason
why I'm running for president of the United

States. To seize this moment, we have to ensure
free and full exchange of information, and

that starts with an open internet. I will
take--I

496.text:

to network neutrality, because once providers

503.text:

509.text:
out and we all lose. The internet is perhaps

515.text:
to keep it that way. To seize this moment,
we have to connect all of America to 21st

527.text:

532.text:

Broadband speed. We will connect schools and

538.text:

on the special interest so that we can finally

542.text:

our safety, our security, and our connectivity.

550.text:

to open up our democracy. It's no coincidence

557.text:

in our history, has favored special interests

562.text:
and pursued policies that could not stand
up to the sunlight. As president, I'm going

567.text:
to change that. We will put government data

574.text:

586.text:
contracts. I'll let you participate in government
forums, ask questions in real time, offer

606.text:

611.text:
make certain that we are always at the forefront

it into every decision that we make. And if
you want to know how I'll govern, just look

at our campaign. We’ve received over 370,000

638.text:
under $25. Nearly 300,000 Americans have their
own accounts on BarackObama.com. They’ve

648.text:

656.text:
ideas, because we believe the real change

662.text:
empowers people to come together to make that
change. Because at this moment, I think we

668.text:
have to do more than to get our house in order,
the opportunity in front of us is bigger than

673.text:
that. Seizing this opportunity is going to
depend on more than what the government does

678.text:
or even what the technology sector does. It's
going to depend on how together we harness

683.text:
technology to confront the biggest challenges
that America faces. Just imagine what we could

689.text:
do. If we commit ourselves to electronic medical
records, then we can lift up the quality of

694.text:
healthcare and reduce error and dramatically
lower costs. If we take on--if we take on

705.text:
special interests and make aggressive investments

710.text:
done with solar here in Mountainview, that
we can end our addiction to ore, create millions

716.text:
of jobs and save the planet in the bargain.
If we make technological literacy a fundamental

722.text:
part of education then we can give our children
the skills they need to compete and ensure

727.text:
the next generation of scientists and engineers

735.text:

741.text:
in the world. If America doesn't seize this

747.text:
from Dubai and Dublin, from Shanghai and Mumbai.
So, instead of George Bush's policy of undermining

755.text:
science, I intend to double federal funding
for basic research and make the R&D tax credit

761.text:
permanent. To keep--to keep the door open
for the next generation of start-ups, I'll

773.text:
enforce tough anti-trust laws, and to ensure
that America continues to track the world's

779.text:
best and brightest, we need comprehensive
immigration reform that strengthens permanent

785.text:
resident visas like the H-1B program. We need
to make sure that the next success story,

798.text:
the next Google, happens here in America.
The Google stories about what can be achieved

805.text:
when we cultivate new ideas and keep the playing
field level for new businesses. But it's also

812.text:
about not settling for what we've already
achieved, it's about constantly raising the

817.text:
bar so that we're more competitive. And so
we use technology to reach ever expanding

822.text:
horizons. You know, the first time I was back
here in 2004, Larry showed me the image that

830.text:
tracks all the internet searches taking place
in the world. I wrote about this in my book.

836.text:

842.text:
languages marking all the traffic on this
wondrous network, the network that didn't

847.text:
even exist when almost all of us here were

859.text:

Most of Africa, chunks of Asia, even parts

868.text:
of the United States, the disconnected corners
of our interconnected world where the promise

875.text:
of the 21st century is being eclipsed by peril.
You and I must not settle for anything less

882.text:
than an America that replaces that darkness
with a new light, because the promise and

888.text:
prosperity of the new economy must not be
the property of the few. It must be a force

894.text:
that lifts up our entire country and ultimately
lifts up the entire world.

907.text:
We have the privilege to live in a transformational
moment, a moment when an idea can change the

914.text:
world, a moment when technology empowers us
to come together as never before while letting

920.text:
each of us reach for our own individual dreams,
a moment when we can finally progress and

927.text:
move beyond the huge challenges that have
stood in the way of progress for far too long.

933.text:
We cannot and we must not look back and regret
that we settled for anything less. And that's

941.text:
why I'm asking you to join me in seizing this
moment, I'm asking you to join me in changing

947.text:
the world. Thank you very much everybody.
Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

1179.text:

1218.text:
we have to make good decisions, so that's

1226.text:
on the special interest in the past and of
one and I've got an instinct of bias to push

1233.text:

1238.text:

1243.text:

1258.text:
